content: The "Clone Pager Authorization Act of 1999" may be cited as the Act. It pertains to the authorization of clone pagers. The "Clone Pager Authorization Act of 1999" amends sections of the United States Code related to the use of pen registers, trap and trace devices, and clone pagers. It requires obtaining a court order before installing or using these devices, except as provided in specific sections or under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. The "Clone Pager Authorization Act of 1999" amends Section 3121 of title 18, United States Code, by adding clone pagers to the list of devices covered. It also requires electronic communication service providers to assist law enforcement officers authorized to use clone pagers. Section 3126 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include reports concerning pen registers, trap and trace devices, and clone pagers. Section 3127 is also amended to define the use of pen registers and trap and trace devices in criminal investigations. The "Clone Pager Authorization Act of 1999" amends Section 3121 of title 18, United States Code, by adding clone pagers to the list of covered devices. It requires assistance from electronic communication service providers for law enforcement officers to use clone pagers as directed by court orders. The Act also addresses emergency installations of pen registers, trap and trace devices, or clone pagers under specific conditions. The "Clone Pager Authorization Act of 1999" amends Chapter 206 of title 18, United States Code by allowing federal and state representatives to apply for court orders authorizing the use of a clone pager. The application must include the identity of the government attorney or state officer. The application for a clone pager must include the identity of the law enforcement agency, the individual using the pager, a description of the device, the offense being investigated, the subject of the investigation, and an affidavit establishing probable cause. An ex parte order authorizing the use of a clone pager within the court's jurisdiction is granted if probable cause is established that information relevant to an ongoing criminal investigation will be obtained through its use. The order must specify the identity of the individual using the numeric display paging device to be cloned. An ex parte order allows the cloning of a numeric display paging device used by an individual, with details such as subscriber identity and related offense. The order is valid for up to 30 days and can be extended if necessary. The clone pager order allows for the cloning of a numeric pager for investigative purposes. Extensions can be granted for up to 30 days, and a report on acquired messages must be submitted to the court. The order also includes a directive for nondisclosure of the clone pager's existence. The use of a clone pager for investigative purposes requires the order to be sealed and prohibits disclosure of its existence. The issuing judge must notify the individual using the cloned pager within 90 days of the order's termination. The use of a clone pager for investigative purposes requires a court order, with details including the date of entry and authorized period of use. The court may delay notifying the individual if good cause is shown. It also introduces new sections 3128 and 3129 related to the application and issuance of orders for the use of a clone pager. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to section 605(a) of title 47, United States Code.
